reviewText: I love this movie and the players in it.  Good story and pleased with it overall.  Highly recommended for Tarzan fans.
Title: Tarzan The Magnificent

reviewText: An interesting film where you have the reigning Tarzan (Gordon Scott) battling the next guy ( Jock Mahoney).  Be kinda like a last Connery Bond film with Roger Moore as the villain!  Escorting a killer to justice (Mahoney), tracked by his band.  Not a bad entry.  Like all WB Archive films, nothing extra.
Title: Tarzan The Magnificent

reviewText: Gordon Scott(ex Las Vegas lifeguard and bodybuilder) arguably the best Tarzan to grace our screens! Supported by top cast with the equally magnificent John Carradine as the villain along with Jock (stuntman) Mahony,who later filled Scott's shoes as the leaner(but good in the role)TarzanColor,African locations,all that's missing is Umgawa!!!!
Title: Tarzan The Magnificent

reviewText: Tarzan was definitely magnificent as the title suggests.  This color film was an excellent entry in the Tarzan series.  Great locations and great acting.  Tarzan fans buy this one.
Title: Tarzan The Magnificent

reviewText: The Tarzan six pack includes:Tarzan`s Hidden Jungle 1955,Tarzan and the Lost Safari 1957,Tarzan and the Trappers 1958,Tarzan`s Fight for Life 1958,Tarzan`s Greatest Adventure 1959,Tarzan The Magnificent 1960Bought at WB shop. What a deal.All six films presented in widescreen !All playback/record fine with no problemson a Toshiba 2003 model recorder/playerand a Sony 2007 model recorder/player.Quality is very good, both video and audio.These are made to order DVD-R discs.Cover art is lacking with few photosand no original poster art?
summary: TARZAN SIX PACK FOR SIXTY BUCKS
Title: Tarzan The Magnificent

reviewText: TARZAN THE MAGNIFICENT(1960) Directed and Written by Robert Day.Starring Gordon Scott. Jock Mahoney, Lionel Jeffries and John Carradine.After a murderous member of the Banton family clan is captured, Tarzan vows to bring him back to civilization so as to collect the reward for the family of the man slain while capturing Banton. There are several problems with this plan. First the Jungle Lord finds himself saddled with a group of civilized Whites who, for a variety of reasons, need to get out of the jungle. This results in the usual tensions and erupting passions that these things always result in...and are made worse by the prisoner crafty Coy Banton plotting always to escape. Second the group is pursued closely by the rest of the Banton family lead by the clever and resourceful Abel Banton intent of freeing his son no matter what the cost.The immediate follow up to the successful TARZAN'S GREATEST CHALLENGE makes several mistakes that keep it from being quite as satisfying. First, except in that here it is Tarzan who is being pursued by five villains instead of doing the pursuing himself, the film is very much a retred rather than an expansion of the "new" Tarzan concept. This would be.......and frequently is--for reasons elaborated later...... just fine save that the script by Day makes four mistakes that prevent the film from being as good as its predecessor.1) Since Tarzan vows to bring Banton back alive and so collect the reward(Though why he could not just drag his corpse or his head back to civilization is never explained---both the print Tarzan and the Tarzan from the previous film would have had no problem with this) the viewer knows that Coy Banton will not be killed.2) A second character needs to get back to civilization so as to provide jobs for the impovershed people of a native village. Thus no matter how annoying he may be, nothing will happen to him.3) Another character finds redemption and gets the girl so no harm in that direction will be forthcoming either. That leaves the two characters who serve no other purpose but to get killed. It is simply too predictable.4) The film---which borrows plot elements from various westerns as 3:10 TO YUMA, THE NAKED SPUR and HIGH NOON---makes the mistake of positioning the prisoner Coy Banton as being Tarzan's main adversary when it should have been his father Abel. So again all this footage is wasted on a conflict where the conclusion is already preordaned by the films's first 15 minutes. Oh we may get a protracted fist fight between Coy and Tarzan but it is mostly unsuccessful since Coy never comes close to being a worthy adversary physically for Tarzan and we already know that---other than a beating---nothing serious will happen to either participant. The film should have moved Mahoney's Coy to second support villain and made the final and major conflict between Tarzan and Abel Banton played by that ace screen villain Carradine.All of the above stated. The film is not bad. It is well directed and photographed throughout. There is never a dull moment. The acting is fine throughout. Someone must have been impressed with Mahoney since he was cast as Tarzan in the next film!!! Jeffrieys as the cowardly blustering rich man brings a certain degree of sympathy to a thankless part. And as might be expected--in what must have been the actor's last major screen villain---John Carradine is very fine playing the exact type of part that he used to essay with such relesh and fun back in the 30s/40s period. Required viewing for the actor's fans.And it needs to said that excepting the lack of a British accent--which the print Tarzan had--when he spoke English---Scott comes very close but not quite to a definitive portrayal of the character. One only wished that he was allowed to be as savage as he was in the previous film and that he was shown..at least..once in either film devouring raw meat from a recent kill.Still not a bad film at all and definately worth a look.
summary: Not magnificent......... but not at all bad either
Title: Tarzan The Magnificent
